content: Since the mid-1980s, Congress has passed legislation to support older youth in foster care through the Chafee Foster Care Independence Program (CFCIP), providing services like housing. States have developed independent living programs with funding from CFCIP to help youth attain self-sufficiency. Federal law also requires child welfare agencies to assist older youth in transitioning from care with written case plans. Despite these efforts, research shows that current and former foster youth face challenges compared to the general population. Research has shown that current and former foster youth face challenges in transitioning to adulthood, including difficulties in higher education, poor health, homelessness, and reliance on public support. Efforts by policy makers and child welfare advocates have brought attention to these challenges, leading Congress to focus on ensuring youth have support systems in place even after reaching legal adulthood. The 110th Congress passed the Fostering Connections to Success and Increasing Adoptions Act of 2008 (P.L. 110-351), addressing challenges faced by youth transitioning from care and providing support beyond age 18. These laws aim to protect older youth, promote normalcy, and respond to children at risk of sex trafficking. This report discusses issues affecting older youth transitioning from foster care into adulthood, focusing on the implementation challenges of P.L. 110-351 and P.L. 113-183.
